country_info.sub_region_name: European Union, United Kingdom, North America, Israel, Australia and New Zealand

indicators.justification:
The statistics are compiled from emissions data submitted to the EU and the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). The dataset contains annual data on the emissions of direct greenhouse gases: carbon dioxide CO2, methane CH4, nitrous oxide N2O, HFC compounds (hydrofluorocarbons), PFC compounds (perfluorocarbons), sulphur hexafluoride SF6, and nitrogen trifluoride NF3. In addition, the following emissions are tabulated: carbon monoxide CO, nitrogen oxides NOx, sulphur dioxide SO2 and non-methane volatile organic compounds i.e. NMVOCs. The emissions are mostly estimated using activity data and emission coefficients. (1)
Emission dataset is also available by location and source of emission, but lacks data about the type of greenhouse gas. (2)

(1): Dataset description, https://www.stat.fi/meta/til/khki_en.html
(2): Greenhouse gas emissions in Finland by province, https://pxnet2.stat.fi/PXWeb/pxweb/en/StatFin/StatFin__ymp__khki/statfin_khki_pxt_122d.px/

evidence.title: Greenhouse gas emissions in Finland

indicators.justification:
No dataset was found that exactly covers the topic of the indicator. Multiple data sources were available, all of which provided a fragmented view of the topic. Therefore the closest matching datasets were selected. The Climate Guide website covers a lot of relevant information, such as gender related impacts (1), and observations of mean temperatures and precipitations and their estimates according to different emission scenarios or impacts of climate change (2). 

(1): https://ilmasto-opas.fi/en/ilmastonmuutos/vaikutukset/-/artikkeli/cb44047f-3177-453f-8b1a-086b1b6da042/sukupuolivaikutukset-suomessa.html
(2): https://ilmasto-opas.fi/en/datat

indicators.justification:
The Finnish Trade Register is a public register that contains information about businesses and companies. As a rule, all businesses have to be registered at the Trade Register. Businesses also have to notify the register of any changes in their registered details. Most businesses must also submit their financial statements (annual accounts) to the register. (1)
Each year the Trade Register registers about 30,000 new businesses;about 115,000 changes to registered company details; and about 175,000 financial statements.(2)
Business ID used in Trade Register equals international VAT identification number (when add FI before the number and leave hyphen out before last number(3)
Statistical information on companies and Trade register is also available(4)
The Trade Register has a joint notification procedure and a information service with the Finnish Tax Administration.(4)
Financial reporting in Trade Register is done according IFRS International Financial Reporting Standards. (5) 
Structured data according HTML ISO-8859-1 in http://avoindata.prh.fi/index_en.html (6)
Act on money laundering (7)

Unlike other details entered in the Finnish Trade Register, the details on beneficial owners are not public. However, the information about the registration of notifications is public. 
https://www.prh.fi/en/kaupparekisteri/beneficial_owner_details/information_services_and_details.html#whocanhaveaccesstothedetailsonbeneficialowners
The PRH also provides details on beneficial owners to those whose purpose of use of the details is in accordance with the Act on Money Laundering. In practice, these include the following:
- Finnish supervisory authorities defined in the Act on Money Laundering;
- companies defined in the Act on Money Laundering who have an obligation to know their customers (such as banks, insurance companies and other financial institutions, real estate agents, auditors);
- media representatives; and
- other parties whose purpose of use of the details is in accordance with the Act on Money Laundering. 
https://www.prh.fi/en/kaupparekisteri/beneficial_owner_details/information_services_and_details.html#whocanhaveaccesstothedetailsonbeneficialowners

Source:
(1)https://www.prh.fi.en/kaupparekisteri.html (2)https://www.ytj.fi/en/index.html 
(3)https://fi.wikipedia.org/wiki/Y-tunnus 
(4)https://www.prh.fi/en/kaupparekisteri/tilastot.html
(5)https://www.ifrs.org/issued-standards/list-of-standards/
(6) https://www.scss.tcd.ie/misc/15445/15445.HTML
(7)https://www.finlex.fi/en/laki/kaannokset/2008/en20080503_20130327.pdf

indicators.justification: The Finnish Trade Register is a public register that contains information about businesses and companies. As a rule, all businesses have to be registered at the Trade Register. Businesses also have to notify the register of any changes in their registered details. Most businesses must also submit their financial statements (annual accounts) to the register. Each year the Trade Register registers about 30,000 new businesses; about 115,000 changes to registered company details; and about 175,000 financial statements.

indicators.justification:
The dataset assessed has data on percantage of population vaccinated by age and geographic area. It also includes information on total number vaccinated, type of vaccine (product) and number of doses given in certain timeframes. (1)
It is probable that residents of long-term care facilities and prisons are included in the data based on their place of residence, but data protection laws disallow specificity of this scale.


(1): COVID-19 vaccination progress, https://thl.fi/fi/tilastot-ja-data/aineistot-ja-palvelut/avoin-data/koronarokotusten-edistyminen-covid-19

indicators.justification:
The Real Estate Register contains data relating to all estates, plots of land, public areas, state-owned forest lands, conservation areas, areas partitioned based on redemption, areas partitioned for public needs, separate reliction areas, and public water areas (1). But the access to the register requires a valid reason, a login account, and information is subject to a fee. As an individual, people can view information about their property or purchase extracts and certificates related to the property.
Ownership data is included in the aggregated Land Information System. Excerpts can be provided free of charge, and the authorities can access the full register for free. (2)
Maps and map projected plot data are provided as open data. (3)

(1): Real Estate Register Act 392/1985, Section 2
(2): https://www.maanmittauslaitos.fi/huoneistot-ja-kiinteistot/asiantuntevalle-kayttajalle/kiinteistotiedot-ja-niiden-hankinta
(3): https://www.maanmittauslaitos.fi/asioi-verkossa/avoimien-aineistojen-tiedostopalvelu

There is structured data available on the approved or enacted budget in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about government budget execution or spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis, including spending in annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about the government's extrabudgetary funds spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about the government's social security spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about public corporations' spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
Budget entries have administrative classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have economic classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have functional classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have program classifications according to an internationally agreed standard.
Information about individual financial transactions or expenditures is available at the most disaggregated level of the economic classification level.
Data is disaggregated by cross-cutting programs, or issues such as SDGs, climate action, gender budgeting, etc,
The data contains common identifiers to connect budget and budget performance data.
The data contains identifiers that can be used to connect budget data with data on major projects (e.g., infrastructure construction) and procurement processes.

indicators.justification:
As there is no legislation on the subject yet, no centralised lobby register exists. Some lobbying organisations and MPs have their own lists of meetings published, on a voluntary basis. Examples include Finance Finland, (1) and the Left Alliance party (2).

indicators.justification:
No government provided datasets were found as there is no legal framework in place for the publication of RTI request data. It is possible that many authorities have their own registers of RTI requests, but none were publicly available.

The tietopyynto.fi service provided by Open Knowledge Finland ry. was until July 2021 a website were anybody could send an RTI request to a public authority and on principle publish the result and time to process of that request. According to OKF only a small fraction of all RTI requests were made through the service, as many journalists and private citizens submit their requests personally. They also estimate that the authorities respond to all RTI requests, and if the request is clear and the document(s) are considered public, such documents are provided. The service was shut down in the July of 2021 out of data protection concerns, such as publishing personal data. The existing data is still available.(1)


(1): https://www.okf.fi/fi/2021/07/15/tietopyynto-fi-tasta-lahin-itsepalveluna/

evidence.title: Tietopyynto.fi

indicators.justification:
All major cities have their own open data portals and strategies. Some smaller municipalities have combined open data portals, such as Southeastern Finland's open data portal Lounaistieto. (1)

In the 6Aika project, the opening of public data is brought into the normal operation of cities and open data is made available to anyone. The cities of Helsinki, Espoo, Vantaa, Tampere, Turku and Oulu are opening their data treasures at an accelerating pace. A total of ca. 60 projects have been launched as part of the strategy, out of which 40 have been European Regional Development Fund projects and 19 European Social Fund projects (in the winter of 2021). (2)(3)

(1): https://data.lounaistieto.fi/en_gb/
(2): https://drive.google.com/file/d/10rVW-LOKVa9fSvOBPmDYv3Rid6d4z6kS/view
(3): https://6aika.fi/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/YhdessaKohtiAvoimenDatanLiiketoimintaa_WEB.pdf

indicators.justification:
Act on Information Management in Public Administration mandates training be made available to "ensure that the personnel and those acting on behalf of the information management entity have adequate knowledge of the provisions, regulations and instructions of the information management entity in force relating to information management, data processing and publicity and secrecy of documents" (1)

Sub-national training is also widely available. Dataset on trainings to city of Helsinki employees by Oiva akatemia lists multiple occasions of ICT training ("tietotekniikkakoulutus"), including open data training and mandatory data protection training. The dataset covers roughly one third of all training provided. (2)

Majority of the training is provided on a as-needed basis. Training might be provided when new legislation comes into effect, or a project requires understanding of certain topics. These include a wide array of data related topics. (3)


(1): Act on Information Management in Public Administration 906/2019, Section 4(2)(3)
(2): https://hri.fi/data/en_GB/dataset/helsingin-kaupungin-henkiloston-koulutukset
(3): Interview with Miina Arajärvi, Ministry of Finance, Senior Specialist.

evidence.title: Act on Information Management in Public Administration

Public servants receive a certification when taking a training so there is a formal recognition as a professional development.

indicators.justification:
As some of the datasets are not available, either due to lack of access or existance, interoperability assessment is difficult. Where datasets have commonalities tracking data flow tends to be possible.

(1): Donors in 2019 parliamentary election, https://www.vaalirahoitusvalvonta.fi/fi/index/vaalirahailmoituksia/raportit/Tietoaineistot/RAHOITUSRIVIT_E_VI_EV2019.csv

indicators.justification:
While the legal framework does not specify what technical standards must be used, it does mandate every agency or authority in the government to have an information management model, (1) coordinated by the Ministry of Finance. (2) The models are kept up-to-date - as per the law. (3)

A project in-progress led by Statistics Finland aims to set quality criteria and minimum metadata for government data.

(3): Act on Information Management in Public Administration 906/2019, Section 6(2)

indicators.justification:
The General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679 is the major element in data protection framework in Finland. The Data Protection Act 1050/2018 specifies and supplements the Regulation. Other laws that apply are the Act on the Protection of Privacy in Working Life 759/2004 (1) and Act on the Processing of Personal Data in Criminal Matters and in Connection with Maintaining National Security 1054/2018 (2)

(1): https://www.finlex.fi/en/laki/kaannokset/2004/en20040759.pdf
(2): https://www.finlex.fi/en/laki/kaannokset/2018/en20181054.pdf

indicators.justification:
Under the Act on the Openness of Government Activities everyone has the right to obtain information from official documents in the public domain. The Act on Openness of Government Activities provides for different ways of obtaining information. Official documents are in the public domain unless specifically otherwise provided for. The principle of openness thus prevails in Finland. (1) The Data Protection gives protection to natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data. (2)

The Government's proposal to Parliament for a new law based on Directive (EU) 2019/1024 on open data and the reuse of PSI states that documents must be "made available in electronic form in all pre-existing formats and in all pre-existing language versions and, where possible and appropriate, in formats that are transparent, machine-readable and accessible, discoverable and re-usable, together with with metadata". (3) The proposal was adopted 23.6.2021 in the Finnish Parliament and will be implemented 17.7.2021 (4)

Programme of Prime Minister Sanna Marin's Government promotes the government officers to deepen their knowledge on open data. (5)

In the 1st of January 2020 the JHS 189 recommendation for open licencing, advising the use of Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 licence, was made obsolete. (6) It is however not discouraged to comply with the recommendation and many government agencies still do. (7)(8)

(1): Act on the Openness of Government Activities 621/1999, https://www.finlex.fi/en/laki/kaannokset/1999/en19990621_20150907.pdf
(2): Data Protection Act 1050/2018, https://www.finlex.fi/en/laki/kaannokset/2018/en20181050.pdf
(3): Government's proposal to Parliament for legislation implementing the Open Data Directive HE 74/2021, https://www.finlex.fi/fi/esitykset/he/2021/20210074
(4): https://www.eduskunta.fi/FI/vaski/EduskunnanVastaus/Sivut/EV_107+2021.aspx
(5): Programme of Prime Minister Sanna Marin's Government 10 December 2019. Inclusive and competent Finland - a socially, economically and ecologically sustainable society, https://julkaisut.valtioneuvosto.fi/handle/10024/161935
(6): https://www.suomidigi.fi/ohjeet-ja-tuki/jhs-suositukset-lakkautetut
(7): https://vayla.fi/en/transport-network/data/open-data/terms-of-use
(8): https://budjetti.vm.fi/indox/opendata/

responses.response_text: The framework assessed covers the national government, but may have some exceptions or may not apply to other levels of government.
responses.subquestion_text: How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the lobbying framework assessed for this question?

indicators.justification:
Only candidates elected are required to disclose information on their election funding. (1) The funding to be disclosed is defined in the law as "the funding raised to cover the costs of the candidate's election campaign incurred over a period starting no earlier than six months before the election day and ending no later than two weeks after the election day irrespective of when such costs are paid." (2) Similarly to a candidate, a political party must disclose the funds raised and spent during a campaign. (3)

While the candidate is not obligated to report their personal income or assets in the election funding disclosure, information on their taxable income is separately available based on their tax assessment. (4)

(1): Act on a Candidate's Election Funding 273/2009 Section 5(1)
(2): Act on a Candidate's Election Funding 273/2009 Section 2
(3): Act on Political Parties 10/1969 Section 9 b (amendment 16.7.2010/683), https://www.finlex.fi/fi/laki/ajantasa/1969/19690010#P9b
(4): Act on the public disclosure and confidentiality of tax information 1346/1999 Section 5

evidence.title: Act on a Candidate’s Election Funding

indicators.justification:
The legal framework for publishing information related to public consultation is based on the Act on the Openness of Government Activities and is therefore somewhat general in its wording. While the law doesn't explicitly require a public consultation process, a government resolution (1) instructs its use in matters of legislation, both domestic and international. 

(1): Government Resolution OM/2016/14, Section 1.1 (https://valtioneuvosto.fi/delegate/file/10704)

evidence.title: Act on the Openness of Government Activities
Legislative Drafting Process Guide: Consultation - finlex.fi
Act on the Statutes of Finland
Guidance based on Government Resolution OM/2016/14

The framework requires the publication of notice of intent in advance of public consultation processes.
The framework requires the publication of proposed regulations.
The framework requires the timely publication of a full set of public comments generated through public consultation processes.

The framework requires the publication of final regulations and justification.
The framework requires the publication of challenges to laws and regulations that have undergone public consultation processes, as well as their results.

indicators.justification:
The basis of RTI legislation is the Act on the Openness of Government Activities. (1) Information relating to RTI requests, and their results would fall under exceptions to the law, which need not be published. (2)
No legal framework was found that would require the publication of RTI performance data.

(1): Act on the Openness of Government Activities 621/1999, Chapter 3
(2): Act on the Openness of Government Activities 621/1999, Section 5(3)

evidence.title: Act on the Openness of Government Activities 621/1999

indicators.justification:
The Sámi people form the majority of reideer herders in Finland.
Research into land use in the case of indigenous people has been done, and it is noted that land use data is not compatible with (oral) traditional knowledge. (1)
There is a general consensus that multiple actors are using land use data, but finding individual cases or organisations is difficult.

(1): Markkula, I., M. T. Turunen, and S. Kantola. 2019. Traditional and local knowledge in land use planning: insights into the use of the Akwé: Kon Guidelines in Eanodat, Finnish Sápmi. Ecology and Society 24(1):20. https://doi.org/10.5751/ES-10735-240120

indicators.justification:
While there have been some exposés, all of the examples found either don't mention the source or the source has been gained via an RTI request.
For example in 2020 the then-Minister of Finance, Katri Kulmuni, resigned after the press exposed her use of government funds for partly personal communication consultation. (1)(2) It should be noted, that there is no information if open Political Integrity data was used.  
It is probable that open data is reviewed by a variety of actors, but there is no evidence of it being used.

(1): YLE, Kulmuni resigns as Minister of Finance over €50k coaching bill, 2020-06-05, https://yle.fi/uutiset/osasto/news/kulmuni_resigns_as_minister_of_finance_over_50k_coaching_bill/11387871
(2): Paananen, Karoliina and Liski, Jarno, Suomen Kuvalehti, Kallista konsultointia, 2020-06-02, https://suomenkuvalehti.fi/jutut/kotimaa/politiikka/kulmuni-kayttanyt-runsaasti-konsultin-apua-muun-muassa-viestien-sparraamiseen-lahes-50-000-euroa-laskua-ministerioihin/

evidence.title: Kulmuni resigns as Minister of Finance over €50k coaching bill

indicators.justification:
The government commisioned a research into improving public procurement, and it was recommended that all procurement data should be aggregated into an open data bank for better analysis. (1)
As part of a larger procurement improvement project, the Ministry of Finance has a sub-project for strengthening "procurement skills" and developing tools for this purpose. (2)

(1): https://julkaisut.valtioneuvosto.fi/bitstream/handle/10024/163212/13-2021-Julkiset%20hankinnat-kokonaisvolyymi%20ja%20datan%20hy%C3%B6dynt%C3%A4minen.pdf
(2): https://vm.fi/hankinnat-hankintataitojen-kehittaminen
